repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR:
* adds new option compiling tests with shared utility module
* adds separated CI run for testing shared utility module

> [!NOTE]  
> Running test with shared utility module enabled:
> * is done in simple way. The shared utility module is compiled for **every** test what is suboptimal. This can be improved compiling once and just copying .so file. To be decided whether it is enough or PR needs more love...
> * is skipping all tests which are not compiled (pure python) or compilation is driven by test itself (.srctree tests)
>
> I was not sure which cases in the matrix should be enabled in CI/CD (which python version etc.), this is to be discussed.

comment_data.body: Now I am thinking maybe the PR deserves better name for argument (and variables too)... `--shared-utility` or `--shared-utility-module`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -171,6 +169,12 @@ jobs:
             backend: "c,cpp"
             env: { LIMITED_API: "--limited-api" }
             extra_hash: "-limited_api"
+          # Cython Shared Module
+          - os: ubuntu-22.04
+            python-version: "3.12"
+            backend: "c,cpp"
+            env: { LIMITED_API: "--shared-module" }
+            extra_hash: "--shared-module"

@@ -171,6 +171,12 @@ jobs:
             backend: "c,cpp"
             env: { LIMITED_API: "--limited-api" }
             extra_hash: "-limited_api"
+          # Cython Shared Module
+          - os: ubuntu-22.04
+            python-version: "3.12"
+            backend: "c,cpp"
+            env: { LIMITED_API: "--shared-module" }

comment_data.body: If you ask me, `--shared-utility` is ok, `--shared-utility-module` is really clear but also a bit long if you need to type it more often (which you probably don't). `--shared-module` does seem rather generic and less clear. But we only have one shared module as it stands, soâ€¦
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -171,6 +169,12 @@ jobs:
             backend: "c,cpp"
             env: { LIMITED_API: "--limited-api" }
             extra_hash: "-limited_api"
+          # Cython Shared Module
+          - os: ubuntu-22.04
+            python-version: "3.12"
+            backend: "c,cpp"
+            env: { LIMITED_API: "--shared-module" }
+            extra_hash: "--shared-module"

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                if self.shared_module is not None and 'shared_module' not in tags['tag']:
                    # EndToEnd tests have their own build setup which doesn't use the shared module unless the tag says so.
                    continue
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +855,9 @@ def handle_directory(self, path, context):
                     continue
                 if skip_limited(tags):
                     continue
+                if self.shared_module is not None and 'shared_module' not in tags['tag']:
+                    # It is redundant to run EndToEnd tests that are not related to using shared utility module
+                    continue

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            if mode == 'run' and ext == '.py' and not filename.startswith('test_') and not (
                    self.cython_only or self.shared_module):
                # additionally test file in real Python
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -881,6 +885,9 @@ def handle_directory(self, path, context):
 
             if mode == 'run' and ext == '.py' and not self.cython_only and not filename.startswith('test_'):
                 # additionally test file in real Python
+                if self.shared_module:
+                    # Without compilation it does not make sense run it with shared utility module enabled
+                    continue

comment_data.body:
`generate_shared_module()` has side-effects, it calls `Errors.reset()`, for example. I think we should avoid giving it side-effects.

Also, this doesn't seem to check if the shared module is already there. I don't think we should build it multiple times. Given its purpose of being reused (and thus saving space and time), we should also build it once in the whole run (like the refnanny) and then reuse it across all tests.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1207,8 +1216,19 @@ def runAbi3AuditTest(self):
         if abi3result.returncode != 0:
             raise RuntimeError(f"ABI3 audit failed:\n{abi3result.stdout}")
 
+    def generateSharedModule(self):
+        from Cython.Build.SharedModule import generate_shared_module
+        from Cython.Compiler.Options import CompilationOptions
+        if self.language == 'cpp':
+            options = CompilationOptions(shared_c_file_path=f'{self.workdir}/{self.shared_module}.cpp')
+        else:
+            options = CompilationOptions(shared_c_file_path=f'{self.workdir}/{self.shared_module}.c')
+        if self.shared_module:
+            generate_shared_module(options)

commit.message: Run tests with shared module enabled
Skip tests which are not related to shared utility module
